content.description: Northeast Arkansas Classic jug thuggin! SDS same as Skywalker but work right like JJ but move up and left at the "rectangle pocket" and finish with a common "Huck Yer Meat" throw to a big square ledge. Finish with a civilized topout and walk off.

For sure the area classic even though it is a contrived eliminate in the begining.  Sds/squat start same as GYN with a heel or toe cam (detached keg-sized boulder below the climb is not on). Move up and left to a incut L-Hand side pull. Get creative with swinging your feet around to maximize opposition on the flake and keep controlled going up to the crimp or pocket depending on which hand you decide on leading off the flake with. One final pop to a jug off the pocket will leave you with a moderate Hobo Beach Grovel Mantle finish and topout. Walk off climbers right.
content.location: Starts above the "Britany" graffiti (at the time writing)

content.description: Ultra Classic. SDS in the very back of the overhang on a big horizontal hollow Hobo flake jug and work left on big holds to a wild under cling compression brick move

SDS/Squat start matched on juggy pinch. Lead with the L-hand to a decent crimp and get the R-Hand on a terrible one, load up, and fire to the jug. Check the swing or dig your toes in and core-up to try and keep your feet on if swingin' ain't your thang.
Start on a jug and move up into the offwidth crack. Either sidepull and chuck for the jug or get creative in the offwidth crack to get to the good jug.
Start on the good jugs and move up and left to a left sidepull jug slot and head straight up.

Possibly still a project. Start in the jug slot a wingspan left of Fraggle Crap. Move up and slightly right to a pinchy rail feature keep the tension and try to get your feet on something higher to make the final move to a jug or just huck your meat.
Same start as PMN but traverse right under the upper mini roof lip to a wide jug slot and then head straight up.
Same start as PP but head more or less straight up.

Squat starton a flat jug left and move straight up to the hollow shark tooth flake. Get creative with heel or toe cams to keep your tension while you tic-tac your way up on positive crimps and a sloper rail. Top out the outcrop and walk back down, climber's right.
content.location: Start between Britany and Shelby graffiti on a flat shelf.

content.description: SDS/Squat start 5' left of Dirty Hookers on a slopey jug. Move up and left to a good corner and use your left bicep power to control your stab to a good horizontal slot jug and follow the good horizontals straight up to probably the tallest topout at Hobo.
SDS on Wild Swingers. Go L-Hand to the rectangle pocket and work up and right into the finish of Gold Grill

SDS in the wide opening in the back of the central overhang with a big starting foot climb up and right and channel your inner Sharma "Psssssssssaaaaaaat!!" and dyno to that crazy square block tooth jug thing. Then slap pull grovel your way to the top. Walk off right.
This one starts out easy enough and you make think the "Joose is Loose" until to make it to that damn heinously thin crimp. Summon some hateful rage and burl through that pain.

Same start as Water Wheel (above the "britany" graffiti) climb up and favor the right side of the mini dihedral/pin seam and make use of the compression block/pinch feature. Look right to the sloper on Pick-a-hold for a good right foot at the topout.

SDS in the back of the overhang lower and to the left of Water Wheel. Traverse up and left for a couple of moves on flat jug horizontal breaks to power some powerful moves to to a bomber flake/tooth feature a big move to a rounded jug. Topout with a standard Hobo Beach mantle grovel-fest and walk off.

Furthest "Right" boulder problem at Hobo. SDS basically on the mini fridge block and good jug slots and head straight up to a standard Hobo Grovel-Fest mantle topout. Sketchy LZ if you don't climb above the grade or have plenty of pads and spots.
content.location: Furthest "Right" boulder problem at Hobo. Starts above a back breaker mini fridge boulder and a few feet left of a pine tree.

content.description: SDS in the back and climb straight out using your power and core to keep the tension or kill your swing if/when your feet cut. Really cool blind chuck to badass sloper pinch and a thankful jug ladder topout of moderate moves between good horizontal jug slots.

Only a few moves on this problem but they will have you reaching for the whiskey bottle to lick your wounds and dull your shattered ego...or perhaps you'll just crush this thing. Squat start in the back of the overhang just behind the tree. Pull from the start to some weird halfway decent crimps and make a powerful and precise move to a three-finger crimp that just seems to be out of reach or you can't quite tag in the correct way to be able to pull through to a triangle jug. Make sure you've cleaned and chalked the final holds to the top out. It would suck to finally make it through the bottom just to get shutdown in the chaos of the thin horizontal bedding above.

SDS on the jug slots with your feet on the kicker boulder below. Head up to a big hole and get creative with kneebars or heel hooks or just claw your way to the king of all Hobo Grovel-Fest topouts. This boulder problem is frustrating for many but an awesome problem that can be done in approach shoes once you unlock the secrets.

Ready for a real Arkansas bouldering experience... complete with sandy landings, broken glass, rednecks getting their trucks stuck out on mudflats, periodic flash flooding, a drunk hobo that's trying to sleep while you're cruxing out over the top of his bed, and the oh-so pungent smell of ConAgra cooking up that fast food pre-mix in the morning...Well you've come to the right place!Welcome to Batesville. Home of the two Mark's - Mark Martin (Nascar Driver - who cares) and most importantly Mark Mobley (Northeast Arkansas Rock God and Legend)....and less notably known for this wild lithified sandy mudroof system locals affectionately call "Hobo Beach".The climbing is steep and powerful. Landings are flat and sandy, just keep an eye out for the glimmer of broken glass or the occasional hypodermic needle. Holds are fine grained texture and soft on the skin. Hobo is a great way to warm up if you have some off the radar projects lurking in the greater Batesville area or you're a local looking for a way to circuit and get stronger on some steep stone.There is some discussion over what exactly in the hell the formation is. Generally, it has been accepted as the Batesville Sandstone but there are some arguments this may be something different entirely.Either way it's here and you are interested in climbing. The rock feels (and sounds) soft and hollow but it is surprising resilient. Surprisingly, holds are rarely known to break.
